content.description:
A true classic for any lazy sun bather who happens upon this Yosemite paradise. This short but sweet climb features easy crimps, jugs, and ledges. Zero protection and a dangerous fall into six inches of water and slippery stones, but well worth it.

Don't fall. Just don't.
content.protection: None, a fleet of pool floaties might work.
content.location: Climb out of the water (after swimming to the base of the rock). You'll find a submerged boulder next to the Jumping Rock, which you can wade from to start the climb. Climb straight up the obvious jugs, crimps, and ridges (middle of the face of the rock).

content.description: WATER START! Climb around the upriver corner of the boulder, indicated by an obvious jug. Traverse around the edge and top out. Hug it tight, you got two feet of water to break your fall (fall shallow). Solid climb with good movement, if this route were anywhere dry, it would be a perfect classic.
content.protection: None. Falling is much more forgiving on this climb than Wet Hug, with a generous volume of water to break your fall. That being said, there is a submerged rock 2-3ft down, so try to fall shallow.
content.location: Right side of the Jumping Rock. There's a foothold that may be underwater and a jug high up on the farthest right corner.

content.description:
Amazing route with real potential, just needs a good cleaning. Start on the crimps on the left hand side of this slightly overhanging feature and move up and to the right to finish on the column uphill. You'll find some of the best holds are covered in moss, so it needs some care. If the top holds were cleaned, this could be some of the best movement and rock quality in the area. Potential direct variations with a sketchy top out.

The block that's falling off the base of the boulder is OFF!
content.location: On the upstream side of One Way Boulder, which is several yards upstream from Jumping Rock. The start of the route is the crimps on the left side of this face. No obvious down climb, so topping out is not recommended. If you do decide to top, down climb the way you came and jump onto a pad.

content.description:
Still a project, perhaps harder than a V4, but a potentially excellent climb. This route follows the large, horizontal overhanging crack on the river facing side of the One Way Boulder. Start on the right side of the face. Follow the crack up and to the left. Needs cleaning to make the rest of the climb possible. If you decide to top, down climb on Feline Party Favor a bit before jumping onto a pad. Basically hand jams and under clings all the way.

Feel free to name it something else if you grab the FA. Top out looks sketch.
content.protection: Pads for the higher portion of the traverse.
content.location:
One Way Boulder, river facing side. Obvious horizontal crack, start is the bottom right of the face.

Start holds

are a sloper and an inverted crimp low on the right side, feel free to try starts lower on the crack, but this felt most natural.
